instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2523: What is 820-2523? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green light ok, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ok, won't turn on (over 10min foreplay)
threads.message:
Hi guys its me again.


This one has no turn-on pads so you have to use your tongue. last joke before giving up - there is 3.3v on <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> but nothing happens when I take this to ground.

It was ld and gave it a bath, green light came on after gently reflowing the SMC with some flux.

L7220 seems not shorted to ground but after applying power and disconnecting, there is a .001 to .003 reading diode mode with respect to ground.

Large mofo this one so I do not know where to go next... I have not tried injecting voltage at all.


Thank you guys.

threads.message: after duke's questions, does this have burned looking crap by <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> like most of these liquid damaged ones do?

threads.message: when you press the power button does <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> rise to 3.3v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green light ok, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ok, won't turn on (over 10min foreplay)
threads.message:
it does not.

measured at <RESISTOR>R7812</RESISTOR>... also checked continuity to <RESISTOR>R7810</RESISTOR>, both resistors at their nominal values.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, green light ok, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ok, won't turn on (over 10min foreplay)
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> high? Does <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> move at all when you press the power button?
